authorsByline: Associated Press, MORGAN LEE, By SUSAN MONTOYA BRYAN, By SUSAN MONTOYA BRYAN and MORGAN LEE
title: Western states seek to end long-running water dispute over dwindling Rio Grande
description: A feud over management of one of North America's longest rivers has been simmering in the courts for years. It reached a boil when the U.S. Supreme Court sent western states and the federal government...
content:
Brian Richter, the group's president, said that over the last couple of decades, New Mexico has lost more than 70% of its reservoir storage along the river while groundwater has been extracted faster than it can be replenished. Add to that New Mexico has fallen behind in its water deliveries to Texas.

Many details — and the price tag — have yet to be worked out, the general counsel for the New Mexico state engineer's office told state lawmakers this month. The Legislature in 2023 set aside $65 million toward the settlements and related infrastructure projects, and the state is tapping additional federal dollars. But it will still need more funds, experts say.

Ben Etcheverry, a board member of the New Mexico Chile Association, said farmers have transitioned to drip irrigation to save water and energy but are continually told they have to do more with even less water and pay higher rates.

“It just becomes a game of whack-a-mole while we try to do better,” he said. “Every time we do better, it seems they turn it into a punishment.”

summary: The New Mexico state engineer's office is working towards ending a long-standing water dispute with the dwindling Rio Grande. Over the past decade, New Mexico has lost over 70% of its reservoir storage and has been extracting groundwater faster than it can be replenished. The state legislature has set aside $65 million for these costs, but experts believe they will need more funds. The New Mexico Chile Association also notes that farmers are being told to do more with less water and pay higher rates.
shortSummary: New Mexico is negotiating with Texas to resolve its long-standing dispute over dwindling reservoir storage and inadequate water supplies, seeking federal funding for necessary repairs.
argos_summary: New Mexico has lost over 70% of its river reservoir storage in recent decades, while groundwater withdrawals outpace recharge, leading to reduced water deliveries to Texas. The state legislature earmarked $65 million for settlements and infrastructure, supplemented by federal funds, but additional financing is still required. Farmers have shifted to drip irrigation to conserve water, yet face increasing costs and pressure to use even less water.
